metadata.case_name: Raghunath Rai Ram Parshad v. Union of India

facts.text: On May 5, 1948, the then Rulers of eight Punjab States including Patiala and Nabha with the concurrence and guarantee of the Government of India entered into a covenant agreeing to unite and integrate their territories in one State with a common executive, legislature and judiciary by the name of Patiala and East Punjab States Union (PEPSU).
By Article III of the covenant, the then Ruler of Patiala became the first President or Raj Pramukh of the Council of Rulers and he is to hold the office during his lifetime.

Article VI of the covenant: The Ruler of each Covenanting State shall make over the administration of his State to the Raj Pramukh no later than August 20, 1948, whereupon all rights, authority and jurisdiction belonging to the Ruler appertaining to the Government vest in the Union; all duties and obligations devolve on the Union; all assets and liabilities become those of the Union; military forces become those of the Union.

Article X provides for formation of Constituent Assembly to frame constitution; it functions as interim Legislature; proviso allows Raj Pramukh to promulgate Ordinances until Constitution comes into operation, with force of law for not more than six months.
PEPSU inaugurated on July 15, 1948; Raj Pramukh took over administration.
Administration of Nabha State taken over by Raj Pramukh on August 20, 1948.

On August 20, 1948, Raj Pramukh promulgated Ordinance No. 1 of 2005 (Patiala and East Punjab States Union Administration Ordinance, 2005): Extends to territories where administration handed over; all laws etc. of Patiala State apply mutatis mutandis to other Covenanting States from that date, repealing prior laws except pending proceedings.

Notification No.35 dated 27-5-05/11-9-1948 notified that Patiala Income-tax Act of 2001 and Rules came into force in Covenanting States from August 20, 1948, repealing prior laws except pending proceedings.
Prior to August 20, 1948, no income-tax law in Nabha State.
On November 14, 1948, Commissioner of Income-tax issued Notification No. 4 dated 29-7-2005 that persons of Nabha and Nalagarh assessed under Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001.

On February 2, 1949, Ordinance 1 of 2005 repealed and replaced by Ordinance No. XVI of 2005 (Patiala and East Punjab States Union General Provisions Administration Ordinance, 2006): Similar provisions, appointed day August 20, 1948.

Ordinance No. 1 of 2006 (Finance Ordinance) promulgated April 13, 1949: Amended Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001 (sections 3,34, new 23B); Section 6 specifies rates for assessment year beginning 1st Baisakh 2006 (previous year ending last Chet 2005).
Petitioner resident of Ateli (formerly Nabha State, now in PEPSU); carries business as Raghunath Rai Ram Parshad; never paid income-tax as no such tax in Nabha.
October 20, 1949: Petitioner served notice under sections 22(2) and 88 of Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001 for return for year 2006 (13-4-1949 to 12-4-1950, previous year 13-4-1948 to 12-4-1949).
December 4, 1949: Petitioner filed return for 2006; assessed February 14, 1950.
May 23, 1950: Notice under section 34 for year ending last Chet 2005 (13-4-1948 to 12-4-1949, previous year 2004: 13-4-1947 to 12-4-1948).
July 9, 1950: Petitioner and others petitioned ITO not to proceed with 2005 assessment.
July 13, 1950: ITO assessed petitioner best judgment under s.34(4) r/w s.22(4) for 2005.
Petitioner and others approached Income Tax Commissioner and Central Board of Revenue without success; no formal appeal filed.
August 10, 1950: Petitioner filed petition under Art.32 praying writ of certiorari quashing assessments for 2004 and 2005 incomes.
During pendency, notice under s.46 for penalty if tax not paid.
Petitioner's grievance: People of Kapurthala assessed for pre-Aug 20,1948 at old lower Kapurthala rates; Nabha people (no prior tax) liable at higher Patiala rates, violating Art.14.

Respondent's affidavit (Sardar Gurbax Singh): For 2005 in Kapurthala, pending cases assessed under old Act; for 2006, Patiala Act uniformly applied everywhere including Kapurthala. No pending cases in Nabha as no prior IT Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether assessment of petitioner's income accrued prior to August 20, 1948 under Patiala Income Tax Act violates Article 14 (equality before law and equal protection).
Whether such assessment deprives petitioner of property without authority of law under Article 31(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Discrimination under Art.14: Kapurthala people pay pre-Aug 20,1948 tax at old lower rates; Nabha people (no prior tax) pay at higher Patiala rates.
Nabha administration taken over only on Aug 20,1948; Patiala IT Act from that date; assessing pre-1948 income illegal, violates Art.31(1) as deprivation of property without authority of law.

respondent_arguments.text: No discrimination: Kapurthala 2005 pending assessments under old law per proviso; 2006 uniform Patiala rates everywhere. No Nabha pendings as no prior IT Act. Proviso reasonable classification.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.14 violation: Discrimination due to no prior Nabha IT Act/pendings, not Ordinances. Pending proceedings completed under prior law is reasonable classification permissible under equal protection.

Art.31(1) not applicable to taxes: Art.265 specifically governs 'no tax levied/collected except by authority of law'; Art.31(1) for other deprivations. Taxation distinct; Art.265 not fundamental right enforceable under Art.32.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Application misconceived; protection from Art.265, enforceable by proper proceedings.

holdings.text: No infringement of Art.14; assessments not violative of Art.31(1) as taxes governed by Art.265.
Application under Art.32 r/w Art.31(1) misconceived for tax matters.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 equality claim rejected; Art.31(1) distinguished from tax levy under Art.265; Art.32 jurisdiction denied for tax.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala Income Tax Act, 2001
statutes_cited.relevance: Law extended to PEPSU; basis for assessments.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala and East Punjab States Union Administration Ordinance, 2005 (No.1 of 2005)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended Patiala laws to Covenanting States from handover date, repealed prior laws except pendings.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala and East Punjab States Union General Provisions Administration Ordinance, 2006 (No.XVI of 2005)
statutes_cited.relevance: Replaced prior Ordinance; similar extension of Patiala laws.

statutes_cited.name: Patiala and East Punjab States Union Finance Ordinance, 2006 (No.1 of 2006)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended Patiala IT Act; set rates for 2006 assessment year.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.31(1) reproduces this without 'in British India'.

outcome.summary: The petition under Article 32 seeking writ of certiorari to quash income tax assessments for years 2005 and 2006 is dismissed as claims under Articles 14 and 31(1) are not made out; tax matters governed by Article 265 not enforceable under Article 32.

key_quotes.text: "No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Article 265, not being in Part III of the Constitution, its protection is not a fundamental right which can be enforced by an application to this Court under article 32."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the provision that pending proceedings should be concluded according to the law applicable at the time when the rights or liabilities accrued and the proceedings commenced is a reasonable law founded upon a reasonable classification"
key_quotes.speaker: court
